content.description:
Unrelenting for its first 40', this packs quite a pump.  Start w/ technical stemming, laybacking and jamming to reach a fixed pin.  Move to the right crack and up to a roof/flake, plug a good cam or two (3/4 Camalot) then make a couple of overhanging layback moves to reach the roof where you may be dismayed to find nothing approaching a rest.  Clip a pin, maybe plug a green Alien, and summon what ever is left in your arms to move right a move that wouldn't be bad in isolation but seems pretty tough after what preceded it to reach the first foothold since you left the ground.  The climbing relents from here but you may be too wasted to notice.

About 5M right of Orphan at a thin crack that leads to a fixed pin.
You don't need a lot of pieces but you do need the right ones.  I remember red Camalot, small nut, fixed pin, #5 Rock, 3 Camalot, 4 Friend. FP, green Alien and #2 Camalot. to get through the difficulties.  I placed a piece or two higher up but don't remember what they were.  Use runners judiciously as the climb weaves around roofs.

Interesting steep route up a series of broken cracks and flakes. More fun than it looks. You can go left at the top and sling a tree or go right and run it out.

Tough to find without a book I'd think. On the right of Block and Tackle, starts at the right of the big roof containing the Block & Tackle route itself.
Natural protection, with ring anchors at the top.

A fun but short route up the prominent Right-Facing corner, with a neat hand traverse crux.

This route tackles the obvious corner just to the left of "Block and Tackle" and a stone's throw left of the Sugarloaf area. Climb up cracks to a stance beneath the roof, and hand traverse out to the left, before mantling up and back right to the chains.
Gear to 2"

A string of "Tricky" moves with decent rests between. Placing and trusting the fiddly, small gear was the real crux for me. The rock at the top was of poorer quality than most of the rock found in murrin.

Left and around the corner from Orphan. The obvious groove when looking back to the right that leads to the visible anchor above, just to the right of a bolted line.
Got a 0.75 in the pocket down low as my first piece, but after that almost all small nuts.
The Block and Tackle area offers some burly crack and roof work in contrast to much of Murrin Park (Nightmare rock excepted!). Block and Tackle (5.11b) is the classic.
